courseTitle: Determining the Ksp of Calcium Hydroxide

pageData.titleName2: Determining the Ksp of Calcium Hydroxide

pageData.text: In this experiment, students will determine the product constant () of calcium hydroxide, a solid that is slightly soluble in water, by titrating a sample of calcium hydroxide with an acid. In Activity 2, a common ion will be added and the of the new solution will be determined.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.altText:
Activity 1: Titration of Saturated Calcium Hydroxide with Hydrochloric Acid – 75 minutes 
Activity 2: Titration of Saturated Calcium Hydroxide + Calcium Chloride with Hydrochloric Acid – 60 minutes

pageData.title: Overview Video: Determining the K<sub>sp</sub> of Calcium Hydroxide
Outcomes
text: Calculate the <button className='glossary-text'>molar solubility</button> of a solution.
Determine the <button className='glossary-text'>K<sub class ='bodysubscript'>sp</sub></button> of a molecule.
Interpret the effect of a common ion on the molar solubility of a solution.

pageData.text: Understandably, the brain is one of the most protected organs in our body. One gatekeeper to this vital organ is the blood-brain barrier, which relies on <button className='glossary-text'>solubility</button> principles to function. This barrier is made up of tightly packed endothelial tissue cells in the brain’s capillaries focused on preventing harmful substances from entering while letting helpful substances through. Substances with high lipid solubility move across the blood-brain barrier by simple diffusion. This includes psychoactive drugs and ethanol, which is why such compounds have a profound effect on our bodies: they cross the blood-brain barrier so easily their uptake in the brain is only limited by the amount of cerebral blood flow<sup class ='bodysubscript'>1</sup>.

The blood-brain barrier presents a challenge when it comes to treating brain conditions with medication.  One blood-brain transport mechanism that researchers hope to leverage is called carrier-mediated transport; it allows the body to transport less soluble substances, such as glucose. It may be possible to transport medication with low solubility in a similar manner.

1Laterra, J., Keep, R., Betz, L. A., & Goldstein, G. W. (1999). Blood-Brain Barrier. In G. J. Siegel, B. W. Agranoff, R. W. Albers, S. K. Fisher, & M. D. Uhler (Eds.), Basic Neurochemistry: Molecular, Cellular and Medical Aspects (6th ed.). essay, Lippincott-Raven.

pageData.desc: A cube of aerogel on display.
pageData.altText: A stylized illustration of a semi-transparent human torso with the brain and spinal cord visible.

pageData.text: An important property of molecules is their , or the degree to which they dissociate in different solvents (water, alcohols, other organic solutions, etc.). Many chemicals have some measureable solubility in a solvent. The general classifications of solubility are insoluble, slightly soluble, or soluble. Insoluble compounds have a maximum concentration (or molarity) of less than 0.01 mol/L. Slightly soluble compounds have a maximum concentration between 0.01 and 0.1 mol/L, whereas soluble compounds have a maximum concentration greater than 0.1 mol/L. solubility is determined using an equilibrium equation between the solid molecule and its dissolved ions. An example using silver sulfide (Ag2S) is given below, where the “s” indicates a solid and the “aq” indicates aqueous ions.
Ag2S (s) ⟷ 2Ag + (aq) + S 2- (aq)
Solubility is determined by the application of an equilibrium equation. Typically, an equilibrium equation is used to determine the equilibrium constant (K<sub class ='bodysubscript'>eq</sub>):
Keq = [A]w [B ]x /[C]y [D ]z

The bracketed letters indicate the concentration of each ion in a reaction, and the exponent is the stoichiometric coefficient of that ion. The products are on the top, and the reactants are on the bottom:
Keq = [Ag +]2 [S 2- ]1 /[Ag2S ]1

However, only aqueous (dissolved) components are included in the equilibrium equation. Because <button className='glossary-text'>solubility</button> is the equilibrium between a solid and its aqueous ions, the overall equilibrium equation can be simplified:
Ksp = [A]w [B ]x
Ksp = [Ag+]2 [S 2-]1
K<sub class ='bodysubscript'>sp</sub> is known as the <button className='glossary-text'>solubility product</button>, which is the product of the concentrations of the ions from a parent molecule.

options.text: The degree to which molecules dissociate in different solvents.
The product of the concentrations of the ions from a parent molecule.
The experimental estimate of the equivalence point.
The number of moles of a molecule that will dissolve in 1 L of solution.
The point at which the moles of acid are exactly equivalent to the moles of base in solution.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Solubility describes the degree to which molecules dissociate in different solvents.

pageData.question: Which of the following describes an ion designated “(aq)” in a chemical reaction?

options.text: It is a dissolved component of the reaction.
It is an undissolved component of the reaction.
It is insoluble in water only.
It is soluble in the gas phase only.
It is insoluble in the gas phase only.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: An ion designated “(aq)” in a chemical reaction is an aqueous ion, meaning it is a dissolved component of the reaction.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Describing something as soluble in chemistry is describing whether something will dissolve in a particular substance. In place of dissolve, chemistry often uses the term dissociates. Solubility, then, is the degree to which molecules dissociate in different solvents (water, alcohols, other organic solutions, etc.). Many chemicals have some measurable solubility in a solvent. The general classifications of solubility are insoluble, slightly soluble, or soluble. Solubilityis determined by the application of an equilibrium equation. However, only aqueous (dissolved) components are included in the equilibrium equation. Because solubility is the equilibrium between a solid and its aqueous ions, the overall equilibrium equation can be simplified, as shown here. Ksp is known as the solubility product, which is the product of the concentrations of the ions from a parent molecule.

Keq = [A]w[B]x /[C]y[D]z

Ksp = [A]w[B]x

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body:
Describing something as soluble in chemistry is describing whether something will dissolve in a particular substance. In place of dissolve, chemistry often uses the term dissociates. Solubility, then, is the degree to which molecules dissociate in different solvents (water, alcohols, other organic solutions, etc.). Many chemicals have some measurable solubility in a solvent. The general classifications of solubility are insoluble, slightly soluble, or soluble. Solubility is determined by the application of an equilibrium equation. However, only aqueous (dissolved) components are included in the equilibrium equation. Because solubility is the equilibrium between a solid and its aqueous ions, the overall equilibrium equation can be simplified, as shown here. Ksp is known as the solubility product, which is the product of the concentrations of the ions from a parent molecule.

Keq = [A]w[B]x /[C]y[D]z

Ksp = [A]w[B]x

pageData.text: At <button className='glossary-text'>standard pressure</button> and temperature (1 atm and 20° C, respectively), Ag<sub class ='bodysubscript'>2</sub>S has a K<sub class ='bodysubscript'>sp</sub> of 6.0 × 10<sup class ='bodysuperscript'>-51</sup>. However, the <button className='glossary-text'>solubility</button> of many solids increases as the temperature of the system increases; thus, K<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>sp</sub> is a fixed value at a given temperature. The K<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>sp</sub> of Ag<sub class ='bodysubscript'>2</sub>S increases with temperature, which leads to increased solubilityof the salt. The <button className='glossary-text'>solubility product</button> can be used to determine the maximum concentration of ions in a solution. Using this information, we can determine the equilibrium concentration of Ag<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>2</sub>S in a saturated solution:
6.0 × 10-51 = [Ag+]2 [S 2- ]1

In this example, the silver and sulfide ions have different stoichiometric ratios. The sulfide ion has the lower coefficient (1 for sulfide versus 2 for silver), so it is assigned the variable “x.” Because there are twice as many silver ions, the silver concentration is represented by “2x.”
6.0 × 10<sup class ='bodysuperscript'>-51</sup> = [2x]<sup class ='bodysuperscript'>2</sup> [x]
Note that when solving for concentration (x), in addition to the concentration of silver being double that of sulfide, it is also raised to the second power.
Therefore, solving for x:

6.0 × 10-51 = 4x3
1.5 × 10-51 = x3
1.4 × 10-17 = x

The calculations indicate that in a saturated solution of silver sulfide, there are 1.4 × 10<sup class ='bodysuperscript'>-17</sup> mol/L of sulfide ions. Thus, because there are twice as many silver ions (2x), the concentration of silver ions at equilibrium in this solution is 2.8 × 10<sup class ='bodysuperscript'>-17</sup> mol/L.

The refers to the number of moles of a molecule that will dissolve in 1 L of solution. In the above example, the molar solubility of silver sulfide is 1.4 x 10-17 mol/L. Molar solubility is determined by dividing the concentration of an ion by its stoichiometric coefficient in the parent molecule.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the solubility of many solids?

options.text: The solubility increases as the temperature of the system increases.
The solubility increases as the temperature of the system decreases.
The solubility is constant as the temperature of the system decreases.
The solubility decreases as the temperature of the system increases.
The solubility is not related to temperature.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The solubility of many solids increases as the temperature of the system increases.

pageData.question: A solid compound has a solubility product of 5.3 x 10<sup class ='bodysuperscript'>-49</sup> at 25° C. Which of the following best describes the solubility product of the compound at 100° C?

options.text: The solubility product increased.
The solubility product is constant regardless of temperature.
The solubility product decreased.
The solubility product is constant because the compound is still a solid.
The solubility product is always zero at 100° C.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The solubility product (K<sub class ='bodysubscript'>sp</sub>) of a solid is a fixed value at a given temperature, therefore the solubility of a compound will vary depending on the temperature at which the compound is dissolved. The solubility of many solids increases as the temperature of the system increases.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Imagine putting table salt into cold water and then putting table salt into boiling water. In which scenario does the salt dissolve fastest? The solubility of many solids, such as table salt, increases as the temperature of the system increases; thus, K<sub class ='bodysubrscript'>sp</sub> is a fixed value at a given temperature.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Imagine putting table salt into cold water and then putting table salt into boiling water. In which scenario does the salt dissolve fastest? The solubility of many solids, such as table salt, increases as the temperature of the system increases; thus, K<sub class ='bodysubscript'>sp</sub> is a fixed value at a given temperature.

pageData.text: In this investigation, you will determine <button className='glossary-text'>K<sub class ='bodysubscript'>sp</sub></button> of calcium hydroxide by titrating a sample of saturated calcium hydroxide [Ca(OH)<sub class ='bodysubscript'>2</sub>] with hydrochloric acid. You will also determine the concentration of each ion in calcium hydroxide and the overall <button className='glossary-text'>molar solubility</button>.

A is the precise addition of a titrant, which is a solution of known concentration and composition, to an analyte, which is a solution of unknown concentration or composition. In this acid-base titration, the titrant calcium hydroxide (a base) is delivered using a syringe in order to measure the volume of base added within an error range of (±0.1 mL).

The <button className='glossary-text'>equivalence point</button> of a titration is the point at which the moles of acid are exactly equivalent to the moles of base in solution. The equivalence point is achieved when sufficient titrant has been added to react with all of the analyte in a given solution. The <button className='glossary-text'>endpoint</button> is the experimental estimate of the equivalence point. In this investigation, the endpoint is identified by a color change in the indicator solution methyl orange. The molarity and volume of the titrant are known, as well as the volume of the analyte. To determine the concentration of the analyte, you must first determine the number of moles of titrant that are needed to reach the endpoint. Next, you will use the balanced chemical equation to calculate the moles of analyte present. Finally, you will use the volume of the analyte to determine the concentration of the analyte.

In Activity 2, the equilibrium will be artificially shifted back toward the solid calcium hydroxide by the addition of calcium chloride. Calcium chloride is exceptionally soluble and will easily dissolve in water. This portion of the investigation demonstrates the common ion effect and its impact on the equilibrium of solutions.
Ca(OH )2(s) ⟷ Ca 2+ (aq) + 2OH - (aq)

By adding more calcium ions in Activity 2, the equilibrium shifts back toward calcium hydroxide, meaning that there should be less hydroxide ion available to react. <button className='glossary-text'>Molar solubility</button> will then be calculated for the sample under these non-standard conditions.

pageData.question: Which of the following aspects about a titrant must be known to perform a titration?

options.text: concentration, volume and composition
concentration only
volume only
K<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>sp</sub> and temperature
volume, composition and temperature

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In a titration, the molarity, volume and composition of the titrant are known.

pageData.question: Which statement best describes the equivalence point of a titration?

options.text: The point at which the moles of acid are equal to the moles of base in solution.
The point at which the moles of acid are less than the moles of base in solution.
The point at which the moles of acid are greater than the moles of base in solution.
The point at which the moles of base are equal to the moles of water in solution.
The point at which the moles of acid are equal to the moles of water in solution.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The equivalence point of a titration is the point at which the moles of acid are exactly equivalent to the moles of base in solution. The equivalence point is achieved when sufficient titrant has been added to react with all the analyte in a solution.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In a titration, the molarity, volume and composition of the titrant are known, as well as the volume of analyte; however, either the concentration or composition of the analyte solution is unknown. The interaction between the titrant and analyte during the titration will yield more information about the analyte. To determine the concentration of the analyte, as you will do in this investigation, you must first determine the number of moles of titrant needed to reach the endpoint. The endpoint is the experimental estimate of the point at which the moles of acid are exactly equivalent to the moles of base in solution. Next, you will use the balanced chemical equation to calculate the moles of analyte present. Finally, you will use the volume of the analyte to determine the concentration of the analyte.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: In a titration, the molarity, volume and composition of the titrant are known, as well as the volume of analyte; however, either the concentration or composition of the analyte solution is unknown. The interaction between the titrant and analyte during the titration will yield more information about the analyte. To determine the concentration of the analyte, as you will do in this investigation, you must first determine the number of moles of titrant needed to reach the endpoint. The endpoint is the experimental estimate of the point at which the moles of acid are exactly equivalent to the moles of base in solution. Next, you will use the balanced chemical equation to calculate the moles of analyte present. Finally, you will use the volume of the analyte to determine the concentration of the analyte.

pageData.desc: This map describes the workflow for Activity 1 of this investigation. Start Activity 1 by measuring the limewater analyte into a flask and adding the methyl orange indicator to the analyte. Then, titrate the analyte with hydrochloric acid until the endpoint is reached. Next, calculate the total volume of hydrochloric acid used. Repeat the titration for a total of three trials. Then, calculate the moles of hydrogen ions delivered in each trial and the moles of hydroxide ions in each sample. Also calculate the moles of calcium ions in each sample. Next, calculate the molar solubility of limewater in each trial and the Ksp for each trial. Finally, calculate the average Ksp.
pageData.altText: This map describes the workflow for Activity 1 of this investigation. Start Activity 1 by measuring the limewater analyte into a flask and adding the methyl orange indicator to the analyte. Then, titrate the analyte with hydrochloric acid until the endpoint is reached. Next, calculate the total volume of hydrochloric acid used. Repeat the titration for a total of three trials. Then, calculate the moles of hydrogen ions delivered in each trial and the moles of hydroxide ions in each sample. Also calculate the moles of calcium ions in each sample. Next, calculate the molar solubility of limewater in each trial and the Ksp for each trial. Finally, calculate the average Ksp.

pageData.desc: This map depicts the workflow for Activity 2. Start Activity 2 by combining limewater and calcium chloride. Next, measure the mixture analyte into the flask and add methyl orange indicator to the analyte. Then, titrate the analyte with hydrochloric acid until the endpoint is reached. Next, calculate the total volume of hydrochloric acid used. Repeat the titrations for a total of three trials. Then, calculate the moles of hydrogen ions delivered in each trial and the moles of hydroxide ions in each sample. Also calculate the moles of calcium ions in each sample. Finally, calculate the molar solubility of limewater in each trial.
pageData.altText: This map depicts the workflow for Activity 2. Start Activity 2 by combining limewater and calcium chloride. Next, measure the mixture analyte into the flask and add methyl orange indicator to the analyte. Then, titrate the analyte with hydrochloric acid until the endpoint is reached. Next, calculate the total volume of hydrochloric acid used. Repeat the titrations for a total of three trials. Then, calculate the moles of hydrogen ions delivered in each trial and the moles of hydroxide ions in each sample. Also calculate the moles of calcium ions in each sample. Finally, calculate the molar solubility of limewater in each trial.

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE) as described in the Safety and Activity sections.
Hydrochloric acid and calcium hydroxide are corrosive. In the event of contact with skin or eyes, the affected area should be immediately flushed with water for 15 minutes.
Calcium chloride can be harmful if swallowed and is a serious eye irritant.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this activity. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activity. Clean up the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: This investigation uses a glass Erlenmeyer flask. Which of the following best describes the safe disposal of broken glass?

options.text: Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in the household garbage.
Pick up the pieces of glass with gloved hands, place the glass in a secondary container, then place the secondary container in a special receptacle on your school’s campus.
Use a broom and dustpan to collect the pieces of glass, then place the glass in a recycling bin.

assestmentData.question: A common ion is introduced to a solution at equilibrium. Which of the following best describes the change in equilibrium and the change in molar solubility of the molecule in this solution?

options.text: equilibrium shifts toward the reactants; molar solubility decreases
equilibrium shifts toward the products; molar solubility increases
equilibrium shifts toward the reactants; molar solubility increases
equilibrium shifts toward the products; molar solubility decreases
equilibrium remains constant; molar solubility decreases

assestmentData.question: Potassium periodate (KIO<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>4</sub>) has a higher K<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>sp</sub> than zinc carbonate (ZnCO<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>3</sub>). Which of the following best describes the difference between these two compounds?

options.text: Potassium periodate is more soluble in water than zinc carbonate.
Zinc carbonate is more soluble in water than potassium periodate.
Potassium periodate is more soluble in lipids than zinc carbonate.
Potassium periodate and zinc carbonate are equally soluble in water.
Zinc carbonate is more soluble at higher temperatures than potassium periodate.

options.text: Hydrochloric acid is the analyte; calcium hydroxide is the titrant; methyl orange is the indicator.
Calcium hydroxide is the analyte; hydrochloric acid is the titrant; methyl orange is the indicator.
Methyl orange is the analyte; calcium chloride is the titrant; hydrochloric acid is the indicator.
Calcium chloride is the analyte; calcium hydroxide is the titrant; hydrochloric acid is the indicator.
Hydrochloric acid is the analyte; calcium chloride is the titrant; calcium hydroxide is the indicator.

35.5 mol/L

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the endpoint of a titration?

options.text: The experimental estimate of the equivalence point.
The point at which there is more titrant than analyte in the solution.
The point at which there is more analyte than titrant in the solution.
The total volume of titrant used in the titration.
The y-intercept of the trendline created from a graph of titration data.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Read procedure thoroughly.
Locate and clean work area.
Gather all needed materials.

In Activity 1, you will conduct three trials of a <button className='glossary-text'>titration</button> of limewater (calcium hydroxide) using hydrochloric acid as the titrant and methyl orange as the indicator. You will then calculate the <button className='glossary-text'>molar solubility</button> of limewater and the average <button className='glossary-text'>K<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>sp</sub></button>.

pages.title: Titration of Saturated Calcium Hydroxide with Hydrochloric Acid (19 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Titration of Saturated Calcium Hydroxide with Hydrochloric Acid (19 steps)

pageData.text: Place the 25-mL flask on the balance. Record the mass in Data Table 1.
Measure 3-mL of limewater with the 10-mL  graduated cylinder.
Pour the limewater into the flask.
Record the exact mass of the flask + limewater in Data Table 1.
Add 5 drops of methyl orange to 3 mL Ca(OH)<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>2</sub>. The color should be yellow.
Fill the syringe with hydrochloric acid, drawing the plunger back with the tip of the syringe positioned in the HCl to fill the syringe. Try to minimize the amount of air in the syringe.
The amount of air in the syringe must be minimized. If there are any air bubbles in the syringe, empty the syringe and refill until no air bubbles are visible.
Record the initial volume of HCl solution in the syringe to the nearest 0.01 mL in your Data Table 1 for Sample 1.
Place the flask containing 3 mL Ca(OH)<sub class= 'bodysubscript'>2</sub> on the white sheet of paper. The white background will make the color change more noticeable.
Read the volume of the syringe at the edge of the plunger.

Add HCl dropwise from the syringe with constant swirling of the flask, until a single drop of HCl causes a color change that persists 20 to 30 seconds after addition. This indicates that the <button className='glossary-text'>endpoint</button> has been reached. The solution should be faintly orange or orange-red in color.
To gain more control of single drops from the syringe, move the plunger by holding it where it enters the syringe instead of pressing the end of the plunger.
Once the endpoint has been reached, record the final volume of HCl left in the syringe in Data Table 1 for Sample 1.
Calculate the total volume of HCl that was required to reach the endpoint by subtracting the end volume from the start volume and record the volume in Data Table 1.
Dispose of the titrated Ca(OH)<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>2</sub> sample in the sink.
Rinse the 25-mL flask with bottled water.
Repeat steps 1–13 for samples 2 and 3, and record the values in Data Table 1.

Calculate the moles of H+ delivered to each sample based on your experimental data and record these values in Data Table 1.
0.1M HCl = 0.1 moles HCl / 1 Liter solution

Calculate the moles of OH- in each sample and record these values in Data Table 1.
H+ + OH- → H2O

Calculate the moles of Ca2+ in each sample and record these values in Data Table 1.
Ca(OH)2 → Ca 2+ + 2OH -

Calculate the of Ca(OH)2 for each sample and record these values in Data Table 1.
Molar solubility = moles / Liter

Calculate the for each trial and the average Ksp and record these values in Data Table 1.
Ksp = [Ca 2+ ] [OH - ]2

CAUTION: Complete all trials and calculations for Activity 1 before continuing to Activity 2. If you wish to perform any additional trials of Activity 1, do so now; the stock limewater solution will be changed permanently at the start of Activity 2.
In Activity 2, you will conduct trials like Activity 1 but with a mixture of limewater and calcium chloride as the analyte.

pages.title: Titration of Saturated Calcium Hydroxide + Calcium Chloride with Hydrochloric Acid (24 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Titration of Saturated Calcium Hydroxide + Calcium Chloride with Hydrochloric Acid (24 steps)

pageData.text: Carefully remove the tip of the limewater bottle.
Place the bottle on the electronic balance and tare the balance.
Add ~0.02–0.04g of calcium chloride to the bottle.
Reinsert the dropper tip and recap the bottle.
Shake thoroughly.
Allow the bottle to sit from approximately 10 minutes.
Place the 25-mL flask on the balance. Record the mass in Data Table 2.
Measure 3 mL of calcium hydroxide + calcium chloride with the 10-mL graduated cylinder.
Pour the calcium hydroxide + calcium chloride into the flask.
Record the exact mass of the flask + calcium hydroxide + calcium chloride in Data Table 2.
Add 5 drops of methyl orange to 3 mL Ca(OH)2.
Fill the syringe with hydrochloric acid. Try to minimize the amount of air in the syringe.
Record the initial volume of HCl solution in the syringe to the nearest 0.01 mL in your Data Table 2 for Sample 1.

Place the flask containing the 3 mL Ca(OH)<sub class ='bodysubscript'>2</sub> + CaCl<sub class ='bodysubscript'>2</sub> on the white sheet of paper. The white background will make the color change more noticeable.

Add HCl dropwise from the syringe with constant swirling of the flask, until a single drop of HCl causes a color change that persists for 20 to 30 seconds after addition. This indicates that the <button className='glossary-text'>endpoint</button> has been reached.
Once the endpoint has been reached, record the final volume of HCl in the syringe in Data Table 2 for Sample 1.
Calculate the total volume of HCl that was required to reach the endpoint and record the data in Data Table 2.
Dispose of the titrated Ca(OH)<sub class ='bodysubscript'>2</sub> + CaCl<sub class ='bodysubscript'>2</sub> sample in the sink.
Rinse the 25-mL flask.
Repeat steps 7–19 for samples 2 and 3 on Data Table 2.

Calculate the moles of H+ delivered to each sample based on your experimental data and record these values in Data Table 2.
0.1M HCl = 0.1 moles HCl / 1 Liter solution

Calculate the moles of OH- in each sample and record these values in Data Table 2.
H+ + OH- → H2O

Calculate the moles of Ca2+ in each sample and record these values in Data Table 2.
Ca(OH)2 → Ca2+ + 2OH-

Calculate the of Ca(OH)2 for each sample and record these values in Data Table 1.
Molar solubility = moles / Liter

text: Dispose of titrated samples in the sink.
Clean and dry the flask and return it to the equipment kit.
The used chemical bottles can be rinsed and disposed in the trash.

text: How was the molar solubility of calcium hydroxide impacted by the addition of calcium chloride?  Why?

pageData.altText: This map describes the workflow for Activity 1 of this investigation. Start Activity 1 by measuring the limewater analyte into a flask and adding the methyl orange indicator to the analyte. Then, titrate the analyte with hydrochloric acid until the endpoint is reached. Next, calculate the total volume of hydrochloric acid used. Repeat the titration for a total of three trials. Then, calculate the moles of hydrogen ions delivered in each trial and the moles of hydroxide ions in each sample. Also calculate the moles of calcium ions in each sample. Next, calculate the molar solubility of limewater in each trial and the Ksp for each trial. Finally, calculate the average Ksp.

This map depicts the workflow for Activity 2. Start Activity 2 by combining limewater and calcium chloride. Next, measure the mixture analyte into the flask and add methyl orange indicator to the analyte. Then, titrate the analyte with hydrochloric acid until the endpoint is reached. Next, calculate the total volume of hydrochloric acid used. Repeat the titrations for a total of three trials. Then, calculate the moles of hydrogen ions delivered in each trial and the moles of hydroxide ions in each sample. Also calculate the moles of calcium ions in each sample. Finally, calculate the molar solubility of limewater in each trial.

data.title: Endpoint
data.content: The experimental estimate of the Equivalence point

data.title: Equivalence point
data.content: The point at which the moles of acid are exactly equivalent to the moles of base in solution

data.title: Molar Solubility
data.content: The number of moles of a molecule that will dissolve in 1 L of solution

data.title: Solubility
data.content: The degree to which molecules dissociate in different solvents (water, alcohols, other organic solutions, etc.)

data.title: Solubility product (K<sub class = 'bodysubscript'>sp</sub>)
data.content: The product of the concentrations of the ions from a parent molecule

data.title: Titration
data.content: The precise addition of a titrant, which is a solution of known concentration and composition, to an analyte, which is a solution of unknown concentration or composition
